ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I improved my Spanish speaking, listening, writing, vocabulary, reading comprehension, and I improved my knowledge of latin history and culture.
I greatly improved my level of comfort with speaking the language. I also gained more cultural insights.

Speaking with greater fluidity and better pronunciation

Writing with correct grammar and more complex sentence constructions

Cultural insights into Spanish-speaking parts of the world
I learned to speak and read Spanish with greater proficiency.

This class improved my Spanish more than I ever imagined. I came into this course having a weak command of written Spanish and barely being able understand spoken spanish at a normal speed. I was very shy to speak as well. I now feel that I can speak and write Spanish in a usable way, and I can comprehend spoken Spanish very well. This class has given me lots of knowledge about grammar and vocabulary, but most importantly it has given me the skills to have meaningful, conversation-speed interactions with people in Spanish.
Reading, writing, speaking Spanish
I developed the ability to speak Spanish and increased my knowledge of Hispanic cultures.
The course taught me fairly well how to improve my speaking and writing skills in Spanish.

Span 130 really doubles down on the grammar and some of the vocab of Span 120, and further introduces more grammar and vocabulary. It is a step up from Span 120 where EVERYTHING is in Spanish, and there is also more writing than 120.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small class size lent itself to more one on one attention from the instructor and greater personalized feedback.

Strengths: A large variety of materials to learn from and practice with, detailed syllabus, detailed instructions for preparing for tests or large assignments

Weaknesses: Canvas modules were not well organized sometimes. The titles of files were not reflective of what the file was, which made finding documents hard. Clearer labeling of files would be great.
This course was extremely strong as is.

Strengths - The daily repetition kept me engaged and led to a rapid increase in my abilities.
Weaknesses - The course sometimes lacked organization in having assignments available on time to be completed.
The course was a lot of work, but that's part of its strengths as well. I had improved a lot by the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Successes: Breakout rooms were used often which was good for small group work

Area for improvement: Instructors could consider allowing students to use the annotate tool on Zoom more often for interactive lectures.

I think that everything suceeded! One small note is that it was a bit hard to know when to volunteer an answer in class without cutting someone else off, but that is just a product of Zoom. I also sometimes did not realize that there was a recorded lecture to watch until late in the day.
Putting us into breakout rooms to work in pairs was helpful because it allowed more participation and immersion into the Spanish language.
Not having a live-lecture every day was a great decision; it reduced zoom fatigue and gave me more time to synthesize what I had learned.
It seemed like the engagement was the same with other classes over zoom, the lectures were set up well for a zoom setting.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. You will receive an excellent professor that wants to see you succeed and has the ability to help you with that.
Yes! It is a lot of work but very rewarding. I saw clear progress in myself.
Yes, it helps improve reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills.
Yes, for the professor. However the format was a bit mechanical.

I would recommend this course extremely highly. My Spanish is now so far ahead of where it was when I started. Once I got used to being out of my comfort zone (I had never been in an immersive second language environment before), the classes were enjoyable and it was fun to use my new skills. I enjoyed I also felt that the workload was reasonable for 1.5 credits, and the assignments were clear and worthwhile .
Absolutely - Great way to learn Spanish.
I would recommend this course. Just know that it may be more difficult than High School Spanish classes. If you work with the Professor though you should be fine.
Yes, it is a major component of strengthening fluency in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Synchronous lectures on M/W/F. Asynchronous activities on T/TH.
Recorded lecture
There were a few redorded classes. Aside from that, approimately three days a week were synchronous and two were asynchronous.

Live virtual seminars MWF
Recorded lectures and other activities TTH
Recorded videos.
